awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Role of geometry in dynamical modeling of human movement: Applications to activity quality assessment across Euclidean, non-Euclidean, and function spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Human movement is a complex multi-dimensional dynamical process arising out of complex non-linear interactions between various muscles and joints as well as interactions with external forces and objects. These physical factors often impose certain analytical constraints on movement data obtained from external sensors, often with associated geometric representations. Examples of such representations abound in the area of human activity analysis, where several contemporary and emerging human shape and movement representations such as silhouettes, stick-figure sequences, orientation signals, and optical- flow have intricate signal spaces, often described in the language of Riemannian geometry.  The research thrusts focus on foundational methods for extracting meaningful dynamical attributes that will dovetail into the application thrust. The application centers on computational modeling of qualities of physical activities from low-fidelity sensing infrastructure, which is an important component for technology-mediated physical rehabilitation and preventive interventions.
 
Classical vector-valued signal processing and machine learning has had a large impact in the area of understanding and modeling human activities, but their applicability is significantly limited when it comes to signal-spaces with non-Euclidean geometry. This research project aims to advance a new class of robust, non-parametric dynamical modeling approaches, which will extend from classical vector-valued observation spaces, to finite-dimensional Riemannian manifolds, as well as to infinite-dimensional function-spaces. In order to be general enough to account for various geometric spaces as mentioned here, a framework that is free of restrictive assumptions on parametric forms of dynamics is needed. Further, integrating dynamical analysis with Riemannian geometric theory allows the analysis to extend to several feature spaces including depth maps, shape sequences, stick-figures, and orientation data, without re-defining the fundamental models for activity analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Measuring and modeling human movement holds the key to several important applications, such as activity tracking from wearables, physical rehabilitation using motion capture, and movement based interactive experiences. Human movement can be measured in many different ways: including from cameras, wearable sensors, pressure platforms, and more. There is no single way in which human movement is computationally represented, for algorithmic processing.

Human movement also exhibits several interesting properties, which can be leveraged in the various end-applications. For example, for physical activity measures, human movement can be done at varying speeds, yet much of the meaning ascribed to the movement remains the same. To develop an algorithm that can be robust to such rate variations is not easy, since rate variation changes the total length of the signal at hand.

In a different context, say using a depth sensor like a Kinect, one can have access to a stick figure or a silhouette, which appears differently depending on the viewing direction between the device and user. In this case, we need algorithms that are not sensitive to the apparent distortions in shape, which are due to viewing perspective, since perspective does not alter the essential features of movement.

In yet another context, in wearable based physical rehabilitation, it is common to attach a device such as an accelerometer to specific parts of the body to measure qualitative aspects of movement, such as smoothness, joint coordination, balance etc. Every time a user attaches the sensor to their bodies, there is usually some amount of variation where the sensor is attached. Even small amounts of sensor misplacement can change the signal characteristics that are measured.

The examples above illustrate that to develop effective algorithms that operate on human activity data, we need to develop robust methods that do not get affected by intrinsic and extrinsic nuisance variables such as rate variations, perspective, and sensor placement. To do this formally, requires us to study signal processing methods from a new perspective. In this project, we drew on methods from areas of mathematics called differential geometry, topology, and group theory, all of which provide much more specific ways to describe and remove these various nuisance variables.

In this project, we made several advancements for developing robust human activity models, with many wide applications, in gesture-based interfaces, health and rehabilitation, city-scale mobility analysis, and more. Many interdisciplinary collaborations were established across these areas. The project resulted in more than 20 publications, including both journals and conferences. We also had many opportunities for presenting the results of the research to broad public audiences through venues such as  Arizona State University's Night of the Open Door, podcasts and interviews with This Week in Machine Learning (TwiML), podcast and interview with the Arizona State Press, and several invited lectures at universities and workshops on these topics.
